pullrequest.title: Start of C interface to transport

content.raw:
I have a few suggestions in the [c\_iface\_caguero](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/branches/compare/c_iface_caguero%0Dc_iface#diff) branch. The main changes are:

* Avoid the `static` variables.
* Create a struct that stores the real transport node and all its publishers.
* A new `ignTransportNodeCreate()` and `ignTransportNodeDestroy()` functions that create and destroy these C transport nodes.

One more comment about this interface. The examples are compiling using a C\+\+ compiler and not a C compiler. Protobuf doesn’t officially generate C code. I know that there are unofficial options but are probably out of our scope. In my opinion the examples are still useful but might confuse some users if they think that they can actually compile them using a C compiler.

Maybe is enough if we add a note at the top of these two examples clarifying that the code will not work with a C compiler unless you use Protobuf C generated code.
content.html:
I have a few suggestions in the c_iface_caguero branch. The main changes are:

  • Avoid the static variables.
  • Create a struct that stores the real transport node and all its publishers.
  • A new ignTransportNodeCreate() and ignTransportNodeDestroy() functions that create and destroy these C transport nodes.

One more comment about this interface. The examples are compiling using a C++ compiler and not a C compiler. Protobuf doesn’t officially generate C code. I know that there are unofficial options but are probably out of our scope. In my opinion the examples are still useful but might confuse some users if they think that they can actually compile them using a C compiler.

Maybe is enough if we add a note at the top of these two examples clarifying that the code will not work with a C compiler unless you use Protobuf C generated code.

pullrequest.title: Start of C interface to transport

content.raw:
> A new `ignTransportNodeCreate()` and `ignTransportNodeDestroy()` functions that create and destroy these C transport nodes.

‌

One more suggestion, I recommend adding an `Unsubscribe` method that does not free memory or make the object invalid when you use it. ROS 2 `rmw` and `rcl` do not have this; unsubscribing requires destroying the whole object. Having that separation would make [this issue](https://github.com/ros2/rclpy/issues/255) in the python interface `rclpy` easier to solve.
content.html:
A new ignTransportNodeCreate() and ignTransportNodeDestroy() functions that create and destroy these C transport nodes.

‌

One more suggestion, I recommend adding an Unsubscribe method that does not free memory or make the object invalid when you use it. ROS 2 rmw and rcl do not have this; unsubscribing requires destroying the whole object. Having that separation would make this issue in the python interface rclpy easier to solve.

pullrequest.title: Start of C interface to transport

content.html:
Based on testing with golang , I have a couple of small requests . Can we update the subscribe function to support another void* argument and to remove the const from arguments ?

Reality is that we will need that to share function pointers with Go.

In order to make it work I updated it this way (actually I 've created a sibling function) :

int ignTransportSubscribeGo(IgnTransportNode _node, const char *_topic,
    void (*_callback)(void *, char *, size_t, char *), void *_user_data)
{
  if (_node >= 0 && _node < static_cast<int>(nodes.size()))
  {
    return nodes[_node]->SubscribeRaw(_topic,
        [_callback, _user_data](const char *_msg,
          const size_t _size,
          const ignition::transport::MessageInfo &_info) -> void {
        _callback(_user_data, const_cast<char *>(_msg), _size, const_cast<char *>(_info.Type().c_str()));
        }) ? 0 : 1;
  }

  return 1;
}

Changes:

  • Note the extra void *user_data argument in the subscribe function and in the callback. The idea is that the subscribing client can pass some “context” that later will be passed in back when the callback is invoked.

    ( in my implementation , I’ve captured the _user_data argument to make this happen)

  • Also note the callback doesn't have "const" arguments (eg. `const char*` was replaced by `char*`). That's needed because in Go we cannot map the const in the func signature.
